Chevron Eastridge Cogen Facility 
Chevron Pipeline & Power
BAKERSFIELD, CALIFORNIA

RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN


EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

The Chevron Pipeline and Power Eastridge Cogeneration facility is located in Bakersfield, California and produces steam and electricity from natural gas. The steam is used for enhanced oil recovery. Electrical power is consumed by Chevron with surplus power being sold to the local utility. An aqueous ammonia process was added to the existing Cogeneration Plant and was started up in 2nd quarter 2000. The ammonia reduces the amount of nitrogen oxides (NOx) in the flue gas, which is accomplished by injecting ammonia vapor in the flue gas just prior to exposure to a catalyst. The resultant chemical reaction reduces the NOx to harmless nitrogen and water. The aqueous ammonia used is a 20% or greater concentration. The maximum quantity of aqueous ammonia at the facility is above EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) threshold quantities, and above the California Accidental Release Prevention Program (CalARP) threshold quantity.

ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION/RESPONSE POLICY

The Eastridge Cogeneration facility has a long-standing commitment to workers and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation and maintenance of the processes. Corporate  policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, trained plant personnel will respond to control and contain the release.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM

The following is a summary of the accident prevention program in place at the plant.  CPP policy is adherence to all federal, state and local laws.  Chevron's Policy 530 Operational Excellence is the governing overarching policy for protecting the safe and health of people and the environment, and to condu

ct operations reliability and efficiently.  In addition, the Operational Excellence Management System (OEMS) is how Chevron systematically manages workforce safety and health, process safety, reliability and integrity, environment, efficiency, security and stakeholder engagement issues.

The Eastridge Cogeneration facility encourages employee participation in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention. Examples of employee participation include updating and compiling technical documents and chemical information to participating as a member of a process hazard analysis (PHA) team. Employees have access to all information created as part of the plant accident prevention program.

SAFETY INFORMATION

The Eastridge Cogeneration facility keeps a variety of technical documents utilized  to maintain safe operation of the processes. These documents address chemical properties and associated hazards, limits for key process parameters and specific chemical inventories, and equipment design basis/configuration information.

Chemical specific information, including exposure hazards and emergency response/exposure treatment considerations, is provided in safety data sheets (SDSs). This information is supplemented by documents specifically addressing known corrosion concerns and any known hazards associated with the inadvertent mixing of chemicals. For specific process areas, the plant has documented safety-related limits for specific process parameters (e.g., temperature, level, composition). The covered process is maintained within these limits using process controls and monitoring instruments, highly trained personnel, and protective instrument systems (e.g., automated shutdown systems). The plant also maintains numerous technical documents  providing information about the design and construction of process equipment. This information includes materials of construction, design pressure and temperature ratings, and electrical rating of equipment. Th

is information, in combination with written procedures and trained personnel, provides a basis for establishing inspection and maintenance activities, as well as for evaluating proposed process and facility changes to ensure safety features in the process are not compromised.

A management of change process is in place and is used to document and manage changes within the plant affecting safety and environment, as well as changes which modify the facility or change operating conditions.

HAZARD REVIEW

The Eastridge Cogeneration facility has a comprehensive program to help ensure hazards associated with the various processes are identified and controlled. Within this program, each process is systematically examined to identify hazards and verify adequate controls are in place to mitigate the hazards.

The Eastridge Cogeneration facility primarily uses the HAZOP (Hazard and Operability) methodology to identify and mitigate process hazards and risks.  The HAZOP methodology is recognized as a systematic and thorough hazard evaluation technique.  The analyses are conducted using a team of people with operating and maintenance experience as well as engineering expertise.  This team identifies and evaluates hazards of the process as well as accident prevention and mitigation measures, and the team makes suggestions for additional prevention and/or mitigation measures as necessary.  

The HAZOP team findings are forwarded to local management for resolution. Implementation of mitigation options in response to HAZOP findings is based on risk ranking assigned by the HAZOP team. This ranking ensures the findings associated with highest risk are prioritized over findings with a lower risk ranking.  All approved mitigation options in response to HAZOP team findings are assigned to responsible personnel and tracked to completion.

To verify the process control functions still adhere to the design intent, the HAZOP is revalidated every five years.  

OPERATING PROCED

URES

The Eastridge Cogeneration facility maintains written operating procedures addressing various modes of process operations, such as (1) unit startup, (2) normal operations, (3) emergency shutdown (4) normal shutdown, and (5) initial startup of a new process. These procedures can be used as a reference by experienced operators and provide a basis for consistent training of new operators. These procedures are periodically reviewed and certified as current and accurate. The procedures are kept current and accurate by reviewing and revising as necessary to reflect changes made through the management of change process. Operating procedures contain upper and lower operating limits and consequence of deviation information.  Operating procedures are readily available. 


TRAINING

To complement the written operating procedures, the Eastridge Cogeneration facility has implemented a refresher training program for all employees involved in operating a process. New operators are evaluated to assess the level of initial training required and appropriate training is provided.  After successfully completing the initial training, a new operator is paired with a senior operator to lean process specific duties and tasks.  Once a new operator demonstrates the ability to safety perform assigned duties and tasks, the operator may then work independently.  All operators periodically read and revalidate the operating procedures to verity the operating procedures are accurate.  Formal operating procedure refresher training is conducted at least every three years.  All operations, maintenance, and construction personnel receive training on plant health/safety hazards and plant emergency procedures before beginning work in the plant.  All training is documented including the means (oral or written tests/quizzes, skills demonstration, etc.) used to verify training is understood.  

MAINTENANCE

The Eastridge Cogeneration facility has well-established practices and procedures i

n place to properly maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, control systems, electrical systems, rotating equipment, and emergency shutdown systems. This comprehensive maintenance program includes:  (1) conducting training, (2) developing written procedures based on manufacturer's recommendations, operations and maintenance history: recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices; (3) performing inspections, tests and preventative maintenance; (4) correcting identified deficiencies; and (5) applying quality assurance measures to ensure proper equipment, components, materials, and spare parts are used when repairs are made.  A computerized maintenance management system is in place to ensure inspections and preventative maintenance activities are performed as required. 

COMPLIANCE AUDITS

Inspections and audits are periodically conducted, at the Eastridge Cogeneration facility to determine whether the procedures and practices required to operate the facility safely are in place and effective.  Compliance audits are conducted at least every three years by at least one person knowledgeable in the process.  Corrective actions are assigned in response to the audit findings are tracked to completion.  The final resolution of each finding is documented, and the two most recent compliance audits reports are retained.

INCIDENT INVESTIGATION

The Eastridge Cogeneration facility promptly investigates high severity Incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in consequences such as, fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury requiring care beyond first aid. The goal of each investigation is to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent or reduce the likelihood of a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident. The investigation team documents findings, develops recommendations to prevent a recurrence, and forwards the results to local

management for resolution. Corrective actions taken in response to the Investigation team's findings and recommendations are tracked to completion. The final resolution of each finding or recommendation is documented, and the investigation results are reviewed with identified employees (Including contractors) who could be affected by the findings. Incident investigation reports are retained for at least five years an the information is reviewed during the next HAZOP revalidation. 

FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY

The Eastridge Cogeneration Facility has not experienced any accident that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage in the last five years.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION

The Eastridge Cogeneration facility maintains a written emergency response program, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance. The procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. In addition, the plant has procedures to address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment, as well as instructions to address the use of emergency response equipment. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform assigned specific emergency response duties. The emergency response program is updated when necessary based on modifications made to the Eastridge Kern River Cogeneration facility processes.   

The overall emergency response program for the Eastridge Cogeneration facility is coordinated with the Ke

rn County Fire Department. The Eastridge Cogeneration facility has around-the-clock communications capability with appropriate public safety officials and/or emergency response organizations (e.g., fire department). This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident. In addition to monthly safety meetings, the Eastridge Cogeneration facility conducts periodic emergency drills involving the plant operators. In addition, the plant operators are given refresher emergency response regarding the hazards of regulated substances in the plant. All plant personnel have undergone hazardous material training and are classified under Level 3 of the Hazwoper designation which covers the First Responder, and First Responder Operational. The supervisor of the facility has also been trained to a level 5 Response level, Incident Commander training.

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

The Eastridge Cogeneration facility will continue to focus on incident free operations (IFO) and the CPP Managing Safe Work (MSW) process which includes safe work practices designed and intended to manage high risk / high consequence work activities. In support of these efforts, the plant will continue to provide training, utilize Job Safety Analysis (JSA), incorporate process safety principles and practices to prevent loss of containment events, and encourage the use of Stop Work Authority when unsafe conditions or actions may be present in the workplace. The plant will also periodically implement changes to the document management system to improve recordkeeping and tracking of any HAZOP and audit recommendations to resolution.
